status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The PWD Roadway Repair Contractor is working on your street performing patch paving. It is an important city service for your neighborhood to provide the best permanent repairs of previous utility excavations or potholes.  The construction process is to dig out 6.5 inches of material and place 5 inches of dense binder hot mix asphalt in 2 lifts. The dense binder gives the patch its strength but is has large stones and is not conducive to providing a smooth ride, the contractor usually within a week comes back and places 1.5 inches of  the top course. The top course is hot mix asphalt  that provides the smooth ride. The street is leafleted before the work begins where it explains that it is a mufti phase construction operation and you should look at the dates since they will change as each construction phases progresses.  Our goal is to allow parking between phases and not post the street for the entire time the work takes place. This is why the contractor repeatedly changes the dates. We spoke to the contractor about his need to be totally accurate when posting and leafleting  for upcoming work. Since this is a patching contract, the contractor may only be on your street for only a short period of time; giving the appearance of not showing up. Sometimes  poor weather, plant breakdowns, or equipment failure occurs which results in the delay of the upcoming work. The CIU spoke to the contractor about his need to do a better job on changing the dates when those situations arise. Any questions you call the City Engineer Marty Lee at  617-755-9119. The city apologizes for the inconvenience this necessary work has caused.  Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. Whenever a utility company or private contractor plans on excavating into the roadway or sidewalks, they must call Dig Safe. It is a State law. All of the other utilities near the pipe or conduit that plans to be excavated must be marked out in the interest of public safety. Paint has to be used, and it must be clearly visible. The City understands the frustration of dig safe markings. We are currently asking them to look into using paint that does not take as long to wear off. Bottom line, the paint marks are required, and eventually they will wear off. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

description: I'm so tired of the amount of prostitution in my neighborhood. I came out of my basement door and was greeted to an empty condom wrapper. This means that while I'm at work, someone is using my back staircase to do unspeakable acts. I was told when I purchased the house that it was frequented by these sorts but today I was fed up. This has got to stop! I'm using this app because it was suggested by a friend that has political ties, so let's see if it works. I know it's hard to catch them in the act but something has to be done. I walk to the corner store and I have to wade through pimps, hoes, and drug addicts. My street is a major thoroughfare between warren street and blue hill which is frequented by police all day. Are you telling me they don't see the half dressed women standing on the corner flagging down cars? I doubt it. Just a heads up to the BPD, if you see a woman standing on a corner around my way, which is not a bus stop, they are probably selling their bodies.

Thank you
T. Walsh

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. All utility companies and private contractors working in the City of Boston are required to order Police details. A Police detail was ordered for this job. The Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) spoke to the contractor and told him that because the police detail was not filled and has to be more vigilant regarding posting accurate detour signs when performing work. He apologized and said that he would do a better job going forward. Sometimes when driving through a work zone you may not see a police officer giving the appearance that a detail was never ordered, however the officer could be up the street performing their duties. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.
